Award.AwardTitle: The benefits of computer game programming: A research synthesis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the past decade, many tools and opportunities have been developed for children and young adults to learn through designing and programming computer games. While each project has contributed its analysis of what can be learned from computer game programming, there has, as yet, been no synthesis across those projects laying out what children learn from computer game programming, the best pedagogical strategies for promoting such learning, and which tools and learning environments promote different kinds of outcomes and for whom. This project?s investigators are using a systematic meta-synthesis methodology to pull together existing research on computer game programming to create such a synthesis. Their meta-synthesis method is a seven-step process that integrates quantitative and qualitative research findings. A panel of content and methodology experts is evaluating the rigor and transparency of the findings at each step of the analysis process. In addition to the results that will be reported, this project also is contributing to the growing body of research on rigorous methodologies for conducting qualitative research syntheses.

Authoring of computer games is increasingly being used as a strategy to attract youngsters to computing and to enhance STEM learning. A systematic synthesis of what has been learned from scientific studies about effective design and use of computer game programming is needed to make what has been learned accessible and available to those who are designing tools for authoring computer games and experiences for learners and who are investigating the roles computer game authoring can play in promoting learning. This is a broad range of audiences and includes researchers, educators, and program developers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of games and learning has exploded in the last decade, with significant advances in leveraging students’ interest in gaming for educational purposes. While most of this work focuses on game play, rather than on game making, the growing interest in teaching children to code, and the large number of freely available game authoring tools has led to the widespread use of computer game programming (CGP) for educational purposes. CGP is widely believed to be an effective strategy for promoting children’s learning and motivation, and while individual research studies have found some promising results, what remains unclear is the extent to which research evidence supports these assumptions.

This synthesis project took a critical look at the extent to which widely held beliefs about the benefits to children of programming games are supported by research evidence. A meta-synthesis method was used to systematically gather and integrate the literature. A comprehensive search resulted in 351 published and unpublished papers from 172 unique authors about K-12 age students designing and/or programming games; the papers include a combination of academic/research and educator perspectives. Of these, 236 were studies or programs about children programming games; the other 115 were literature reviews, game design only or descriptions of a programming tool or pedagogy, and were not included in the next phase of the synthesis. Out of the 236 articles, another 67 were dropped from further consideration because they had only a description of a program and no data or stated outcomes. The remaining 169 papers were read in detail, and key information was extracted to determine whether there was sufficient detail about the study participants, methods, and results to move them to the next step of the meta-analysis. A total of 88 papers met these quality criteria, and were included in a systematic analysis to identify themes and higher level conclusions.

The results provide information about the kind and extent of research evidence that supports assumptions that CGP benefits children’s learning and motivation. There is evidence that teaching children to use academic concepts to make games has benefits for academic learning, particularly in the domains of math and digital media. There is also evidence that children can engage in scientific thinking when making games, but little evidence that this aspect of learning changes over time. The strongest evidence was that making educational games leads to increases in scientific and mathematical knowledge, however, there is little evidence that CGP has benefits above and beyond traditional education approaches.  The evidence for how CGP benefits computer science learning is sparse, but suggests that certain pedagogical approaches were more likely to result in students using or gaining problem solving skills, while others were associated with programming knowledge. In particular, there is evidence that teaching approaches that involve feedback from others on their game can enhance problem solving, while a focus on incremental and hands-on learning of programming concepts is associated with program knowledge, particularly for less experienced students.

The findings will inform educators about which approaches to teaching computer game programming to children are evidence-based, and will help researchers to identify knowledge gaps. However, despite the promising results, the depth and breadth of evidence is limited as well as the completeness of reports on study outcomes, methods, demographics and pedagogical details.
